thread.title: Power lines, trees down as thunderstorms move through North Central Florida
thread.title_full: Power lines, trees down as thunderstorms move through North Central Florida

author: @wcjb20
title: Power lines, trees down as thunderstorms move through North Central Florida
text: Power lines, trees down as thunderstorms move through North Central Florida GAINESVILLE, Fla. (WCJB) - Emergency crews are responding to downed trees and power lines causing power outages and blocking roadways in North Central Florida as thunderstorms move through the area. Alachua County Emergency Management officials are reporting downed powerlines throughout the county. They warn residents to never handle downed power lines. Weather Forecast: [Stormy at Times Today; Nice Weekend Ahead!](https://www.wcjb.com/2024/05/10/weather-forecast-stormy-times-today-nice-weekend-ahead/) Columbia County Sheriff’s deputies responded to reports of a tree on a mobile home off Country Club Road. The tree split the home in half, thankfully no one was hurt. Emergency crews are responding to damage throughout the county. In Suwannee County, Superintendent Ted Rough announced the school district will release school early due to the severe storms and resulting power outages. Bus routes will begin to run at 12:30 p.m. Student drivers will be dismissed. As of 11 a.m. on Friday, more than 200,000 households in North Florida were [ without power](https://poweroutage.us/area/state/florida). In the city of Alachua, officers notified residents of a large tree blocking County Road 235A about a mile north of Santa Fe High School.
